crypto999#4866
Content: How does BarterDEX autosplit funds to match available orders without having to create a new transaction?

Author: crypto999#4866
Content: As theÂ BarterDEXÂ GUI evolves, the handling ofÂ UTXOâ€™s will ultimately be handled seamlessly in the background using automated trade-bots. We already have implemented a process that automatically splits the user balance as necessary, to match the exact value of available orders. Note that these particular trading bots are performing the atomic swaps on your behalf! These are not average tradebots as seen on centralized exchanges, they trade through atomic swaps. Even though this approach more complex than a generic centralized exchange, ultimately it puts more power back into the hands of the users.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
@SadykovT thanks for your feedback.

I'm aware of the withdrawal issue, it appears to be either a mm or possibly Electrum issue. Other users have reported the same issue using the mm daemon directly. To be clear, HyperDEX is just a GUI layer on top of mm. If mm responds responds saying the withdrawal was successful then the GUI (HyperDEX) will display a notification saying the withdrawal is successful, that is functioning as expected.

We are aware of performance issues with mm and have been reporting them since we started developing HyperDEX. mm and HyperDEX are developed by two separate development teams. We have reported perf issues to the mm team and they are working on mmv2 which will hopefully address these issues.

Regarding the interface not being clear, are you referring to the actual visual design or the way it works? Any feedback you've got here or issues you encounter would definitely be appreciated. Feel free to discuss them in here. However if you have specific issue/suggestion/bug it may be best to create a GitHub issue with the "Feedback" button in the app so we can track it make sure we get the issue resolved.

If trades matched reliably, i doubt thereâ€™d be any confusion over the HyperDex interface. As a new user, without a trade gong though successfully, itâ€™s not surprising to start questioning if the GUI is responsible.

Author: crypto999#4866
Content: Can someone explain why the bobdeposit step is necessary? It says in the literature that this is to promote Bob moving forward with the trade, but my understanding was the transaction activity was done automatically once both parties had committed to the trade? Is that not the case? Do individuals have to confirm each of the steps manually? It seems to add an extra layer of complexity as well as risk to the Bob side...

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content:
@crypto999 Hi, swap protocol design discussions took place at 2015-2016: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=1340621.msg13828271#msg13828271, https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=1364951 when there were just few coins with BIP65 (CLTV) support. The purpose was to allow one side of swap to send standard 2of2 multisig output so at least  Alice can swap the coin without CLTV.
Nowadays most coins have CLTV opcode support so swap protocol will be simplified in MM2, both payments will be hash/time locked outputs, Bob won't need 212% balance to trade anymore.

Author: crypto999#4866
Content: Ah, fantastic. Think that wo uld make things much more user friendly. Can I ask too about the SpeedMode/Zeroconf? It sounds like this could be expanded to allow instant non-swap transfers for a range of coins - effectively a multi-coin Lightning Network as it seems to work in a similar way with the providing of collateral on a payment channel...

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: @crypto999 We don't have plans about Zeroconf expansion/improvement yet. On current development stage MM2 doesn't even support it. We will think about possible improvements when we start porting the Zeroconf to MM2.

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: so currently volume is low for most pairs because not enough people are using it. "This swap is worth $.." should be an estimate of what the swap is worth in fiat. So if you trade 10 kmd for X number of Verus (example) it should say this swap is worth ~ $7. Im going off memory. I think avg vol is the avg vol of available utxos. Max vol i think is the largest utxo. Atomic swaps basically swap one utxo size for another of equal value. Hyperdex helps in creating a utxo for the size you are trying to swap for. What pairs are you looking to trade? @stock999

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: You can read up on barterdex here  https://docs.komodoplatform.com/home-barterDEX.html       Hyperdex is just a gui for barterdex backend. Maybe there is some useful info there for you. @stock999

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: @stock999 also as an fyi, currently barterdex is running marketmaker 1.0 (think of it as the brains that allow for atomic swaps). There is an upgrade early next year to mm2.0 (marketmaker 2.0) that should make things alot smoother. AND there is a project (coincollect) that is working on a mobile trading app with barterdex backend. The project is also advertising providing liquidity to jump start the app use. tagging @Diesmaster to make sure i captured coincollect project correctly.
